Credibility_Assessment: Questioned due to inconsistencies, lack of reporting threats, and absence of corroborative evidence
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to alleged threats in Rwanda

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant re-entered Canada after deportation and reported home break-ins and threats from Delroy Wright
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Deported individual seeking protection upon re-entry
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to re-entry after deportation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: PRRA officer failed to clearly analyze whether evidence constituted new information under section 113

Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, decision set aside

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Evaluation of new evidence in PRRA

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Evaluation of new evidence in PRRA

Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Recent threats and break-ins
Crimes.Legal_Standard: New evidence must be assessed even if prior risks were known

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in rejecting refugee claims based on factual and procedural grounds

Legal_Issue: Whether the respondent met the residence requirements under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Outcome: Appeal allowed, original decision set aside, case referred to a new citizenship judge
Credibility_Assessment: Respondent's claims were inconsistent and lacked sufficient supporting evidence
Evidence_Type: Incomplete, vague, and inconsistent documents regarding physical presence in Canada
Legal_Provision: Paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act requiring 1095 days of residency over four years
Basis_of_Claim: Alleged failure to meet Canadian citizenship residency requirements
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Insufficient evidence of physical presence and lack of clarity in judicial reasoning
Proceeding_Type: Appeal under subsection 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Error: Failure to specify which residency test was applied and inadequate justification
Assessment_Standard: Three judicial approaches: strict physical presence, strong attachment to Canada, or place of centralized existence

Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of the citizenship judge's decision
Application_Factor: Duration and quality of physical presence in Canada
Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by a new citizenship judge
Document_Fraud: Implied through submission of incomplete and inconsistent documents

Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms, precedent on bias and compelled testimony
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No evidence of bias or disguised extradition; hearing allowed to proceed
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Lebanese citizen with U.S. fraud convictions
Crimes.Credibility: Claims of bias and compulsion found premature or unsubstantiated
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Risk of removal based on foreign conviction

Crimes.Crime_Name: Compelling testimony concerns under Charter rights
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of potential Charter violations in immigration hearing
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Charter of Rights and Freedoms s. 7, IRPA
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of self-incrimination if compelled to testify
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: No actual compulsion yet; issue not ripe for review
Crimes.Credibility: Concerns acknowledged but not actionable at this stage

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Admissibility based on foreign fraud convictions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Potential self-incrimination and procedural fairness in admissibility hearing
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No finding of dishonesty in application; focus on procedural issues
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Foreign criminal record, judicial findings
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 36(2)(a) – inadmissibility for serious criminality
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: U.S. fraud convictions rendering applicant inadmissible
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Existence of final foreign criminal conviction
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None noted
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard of review: reasonableness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Foreign conviction as basis for inadmissibility

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Availability of state protection in Mexico
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review allowed, case remanded for redetermination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's personal circumstances and experiences were not adequately assessed
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to stalking by politically connected individual
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Systemic corruption and impunity in Mexico
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Refugee hearing before the Immigration and Refugee Board
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to properly analyze contradictory evidence
Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of retaliation after filing complaint
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Presumption of state protection unless rebutted by clear and convincing evidence
Crimes.Application_Factor: Gender-related violence and vulnerability

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Political connections of perpetrator, ongoing threats, history of stalking
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Pattern of threatening behavior and intimidation
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of harm if returned to Mexico
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to establish credible basis for fear
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board failed to justify dismissal of applicant's account

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Power imbalance, political connections of perpetrator, lack of legal recourse
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: History of sexual assault and stalking
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: Severe – non-consensual sexual acts and coercion
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on gender and vulnerability
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Strong – supported by personal and contextual evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s account dismissed without adequate reason
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 97(1) IRPA – Risk of cruel and unusual treatment

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Repeated incidents, threats, lack of police response
Crimes.Threat_Source: Same perpetrator as in other crimes
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible and corroborated by systemic evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board failed to engage with applicant’s lived experience
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 96 and 97 IRPA – Refugee and protection grounds

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Use of political influence to obstruct justice, prolonged duration
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – linked to threats and violence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s fear reasonably grounded
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 97(1)(a) IRPA – Danger of torture or cruel treatment

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection based on state failure
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Inability to access state protection due to corruption
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International refugee law, domestic administrative law
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Inadequate due to corruption and impunity
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Political connections of perpetrator undermining rule of law
Crimes.Credibility: Supported by documentary and personal evidence
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Systemic failure to protect vulnerable individuals
Crimes.Victim_Basis: Gender and lack of political power

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure of state to provide effective legal remedies
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Principles of access to justice under IRPA and international law
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant reported crimes but was discouraged from pursuing justice
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Lawful presence in Canada pending determination
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable – refers to state conduct, not applicant
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Board failed to assess practical availability of protection
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Extraterritorial application of Canadian protection standards
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board ignored evidence of ineffective remedies
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant deemed credible
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Recognition as person in need of protection
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient analysis of state protection availability

Crimes.Crime_Name: Indirect misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether a permanent resident is inadmissible for indirectly misrepresenting material facts as a dependant of a principal applicant who misrepresented
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not directly assessed; reliance on principal applicant's application
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Application documents, undisclosed prior marriage and child
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Indirect misrepresentation through inclusion in spouse's application containing false information
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Dependence on principal applicant's misrepresented application
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Exclusion order appeal and judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose prior marriage and child by principal applicant
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None noted; all relevant facts considered
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Interpretation of 'indirectly' under s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Application_Factor: Status as dependent family member
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Exclusion order upheld, judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No direct document fraud by applicant, but application based on incomplete disclosure

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose material facts in immigration application
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility due to omission of material facts
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether a permanent resident is inadmissible for failing to disclose material facts as a dependant on a misrepresentative application
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Outcome: Applicant found inadmissible due to indirect misrepresentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant unaware of misrepresentation, but deemed responsible by association
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration application records, proof of prior marriage and child
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Withholding of material facts by principal applicant affecting dependant’s admissibility
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Derivative liability as a dependant on a fraudulent application
Crimes.Application_Error: Omission of prior marital status and child by principal applicant
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No indication that relevant evidence was ignored
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Interpretation of material fact withholding under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Inclusion as dependent in principal applicant’s application
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No personal document fraud, but application tainted by principal’s omissions

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in rejecting the LP membership card as fraudulent without forensic analysis
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board found the Applicant's explanation regarding the incomplete seal unconvincing
Crimes.Evidence_Type: LP membership card with incomplete seal
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section related to document authenticity and refugee claim assessment
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Political persecution
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Incomplete seal on the LP membership card indicating possible tampering
Crimes.Application_Error: None found – Board’s decision not patently unreasonable
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Applicant's explanation for the incomplete seal
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decisions
Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of specialized knowledge by the Board
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Rejection of document and adverse credibility finding upheld
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Altered or incomplete official seal on membership card

Crimes.Violation_Type: Misrepresentation in support of refugee claim
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – Misrepresentation provisions
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant presented an LP membership card with signs of tampering
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Not applicable – claim based on fear of return
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Submission of a document with an incomplete seal without credible explanation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Need for forensic analysis vs. reliance on expert assessment
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of the Board to assess document authenticity
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of forensic testing requested by applicant
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's explanation for discrepancy not accepted
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Certification of question and overturning of decision
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Board used expertise and provided opportunity to respond

Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of IRB decision on refugee claim
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) sections 96, 97, and 72
Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; Board's decision upheld
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's testimony found embellished; lack of subjective fear
Evidence_Type: Testimony, travel history, failure to seek asylum in the US
Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 96 (refugee definition), s. 97 (protection), s. 72 (judicial review)
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility of applicant and presence of subjective fear
Application_Error: Failure to seek asylum during 15-year stay in the US
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness for factual/mixed questions; correctness for legal questions
Legal_Standard: Convention refugee status requires credible risk of persecution
Application_Factor: Generalized violence in Haiti insufficient for refugee status
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied; judicial review dismissed
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Suspicion of Illegal Work under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer's refusal was based on reasonable suspicion of illegal work or non-compliance with visa terms
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.22(2)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's credibility not properly assessed; suspicions not supported by evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Ties to Bolivia, compliance history with immigration rules
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Unfounded suspicion of illegal work and failure to depart post-visa
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of factual basis for suspicion beyond age and marital status
Crimes.Application_Error: Use of standardized refusal templates, clerical errors
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of decision based on known facts
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Applicant's strong ties to home country and prior compliance with immigration laws
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonable inference from established facts required
Crimes.Application_Factor: Dual intention (study and potential future work) considered improperly
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal found unreasonable; case referred for redetermination

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the refusal of Ms. Sempertegui's application was reasonable under IRPA
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.22(2)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant demonstrated credibility through documented ties and compliance
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Proof of residence, family and employment ties in Bolivia, immigration compliance history
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s.22(2) – dual intention not grounds for refusal
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Unfounded suspicion of illegal work and procedural errors in assessment
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to consider relevant evidence and reliance on incorrect assumptions
Crimes.Application_Error: Clerical error and use of generic refusal reasoning
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness and fairness in evaluating intent and compliance
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of strong familial, professional, and financial ties to Bolivia
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Burden on applicant to show intent to leave Canada after studies; must be assessed fairly
Crimes.Application_Factor: Intent to study in Canada while maintaining permanent residence in Bolivia
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Original decision set aside; remitted to new officer for redetermination

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Existence of public legal duty for mandamus
Crimes.Governing_Law: Federal Courts Act, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No evidence provided by applicant to support claim
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lack of evidence regarding Charter violation or public duty
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Request for Canadian government intervention in foreign criminal proceedings
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Foreign affairs fall under Crown prerogative
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to establish public legal duty
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Mandamus requirements: public duty, clear right, practical value
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Mandamus standard of review
Crimes.Application_Factor: Post-deportation request for intervention

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, denied refugee status, deported
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to comply with visa conditions
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Canadian courts lack jurisdiction over foreign criminal proceedings
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Record of deportation and conviction in China
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence of Charter violation or duty to act
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No credibility finding made; lack of legal basis
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Government response regarding trial in China
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No public legal duty exists post-deportation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of work permit refusal and request for intervention
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Existence of public legal duty for mandamus following deportation
Crimes.Governing_Law: Federal Courts Act, Charter of Rights and Freedoms, IRPR
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No evidence submitted to support entitlement to relief
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Absence of proof of Charter breach or governmental duty
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Request for Canadian government action regarding trial in China
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Foreign national outside Canada; no Charter violation
Crimes.Application_Error: Misunderstanding of Crown's foreign affairs prerogative
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard for issuing writ of mandamus
Crimes.Application_Factor: Conviction in China for contract fraud after deportation
Crimes.Authority: Immigration authorities and Department of Foreign Affairs

Legal_Issue: Was the Board's decision to reject the applicant's refugee claim based on reasonable grounds?
Governing_Law: subsection 18.1(4) of the Federal Court Act
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; no certification questions raised
Credibility_Assessment: The Board questioned inconsistencies in the applicant's testimony, lack of supporting documentation, and contradictions regarding his US asylum claim
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility doubts due to inconsistent statements and lack of evidence

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 40(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, had a pending permanent residence application, and sought deferral of removal based on best interests of children
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Request for deferral of removal denied by removals officer
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Pending PR application, existence of Canadian-born children, mother's ability to care with social support
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal based on family ties and children's best interests
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of removal officer's decision
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the child (short-term consideration)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably considered short-term interests of children; mother could provide care with available support; delays in applicant’s process weighed against deferral
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Removals Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 44(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after removal order issued, requested deferral based on impact on children
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national subject to enforceable removal order
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to failure to depart after removal order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Deferral request denied; judicial review filed
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Mother's caregiving capacity, social support network, timing of PR application
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of removal based on humanitarian considerations
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Limited discretion to defer removal based on exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Removals officer reasonably exercised discretion; short-term interests of children were acknowledged but did not outweigh enforcement of removal order
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Removals Officer, Canada Border Services Agency

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether removal should be deferred due to family hardship
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations due to family ties
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Timing of PR application after removal became enforceable
Crimes.Application_Error: Late submission of PR application after removal order enforceable
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Best interests of the child (limited scope)
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of administrative decision
Crimes.Application_Factor: Presence of Canadian-born children

Application_Facts: Applicant faced marital violence and claimed officer ignored relevant guidelines; sponsorship withdrawn due to marital breakdown and domestic violence
Claimant_Status: Applicant seeking landing on humanitarian grounds
Procedural_Issue: Alleged procedural unfairness in decision-making, including failure to follow immigration guidelines
Evidence_Used: Applicant's claims of domestic violence and disproportionate hardship upon return
Decision_Outcome: Immigration officer denied landing on humanitarian grounds
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of the immigration officer's decision
Decision_Rationale: Guidelines in the Immigration Manual are non-binding; officer considered disproportionate hardship and allowed applicant to present her case, thus procedural fairness was upheld

Legal_Issue: Validity of Novartis's patent based on utility, obviousness, and sufficiency
Evidence_Assessment: Expert testimonies were considered to assess utility, obviousness, and disclosure
Decision_Outcome: Compound claims upheld as valid; use claims found lacking in utility
Burden_of_Proof: Teva bore the burden to prove invalidity of the patent
Credibility_Factor: Court relied on expert evidence and technical analysis
Legal_Rule: Patent must demonstrate utility, non-obviousness, and sufficient disclosure under Canadian law
Standard_of_Review: Balance of probabilities for patent validity challenges
Outcome_on_Merits: Novartis succeeded in defending patent validity except on use claims
Key_Evidence_Considered: Demonstrated or predicted efficacy, prior art compounds, clarity of patent disclosure
Defendant_Response: Teva alleged inutility, obviousness, and insufficiency to invalidate the patent
Evidence_Type: Scientific data, expert testimony, prior art references
Remedy_Requested: Novartis requested prohibition of Teva’s Notice of Compliance
Outcome: Court granted Novartis’s request, barring Teva from market entry until patent expiry
Legal_Provision: Provisions of the Canadian Patent Act relating to utility, obviousness, and sufficiency

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness, reasonableness of decision, adequacy of reasons
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.40(1)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies in employment claims verified during site visits
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unfairness or unreasonableness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's explanations found implausible by officer
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Misrepresentation must be material and could induce administrative error
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged misrepresentation based on inconsistent employment details
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Site visit findings, GCMS notes, applicant responses
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, official notes, statements

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness and procedural fairness of misrepresentation finding
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.40(1)
Crimes.Outcome: Applicant found inadmissible, judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims contradicted by employee statements
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Employment records, third-party statements, application documents
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: False employment status claimed by applicant
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Numerous inconsistencies between claims and verified facts
Crimes.Application_Error: Material misrepresentation that could induce administrative error
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Objective assessment of whether misrepresentation occurred
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None noted – all relevant evidence considered
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation under IRPA does not require intent
Crimes.Application_Factor: Inconsistencies in employment details raised suspicion
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Not explicitly alleged, but false information submitted

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Violation_Type: Failure to properly assess risk in pre-removal context
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed risk of persecution in Sri Lanka as a failed asylum seeker; Tamil ethnicity; new evidence included father's letter and police report indicating threats
Claimant_Status: Failed asylum seeker, Permanent Resident subject to removal
Procedural_Issue: PRRA Officer improperly excluded new evidence; applied incorrect legal test ('personalized risk'); failed to consider updated UNHCR Guidelines
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer failed to consider new evidence and updated country conditions
Outcome: Judicial review granted; decision set aside
Relief_Sought: Allowance of PRRA application based on risk of persecution
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of PRRA application by a different officer with consideration of new evidence
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness for mixed fact and law; Correctness for pure legal questions
Decision_Rationale: PRRA Officer's decision was unreasonable due to exclusion of evidence, incorrect legal test, and failure to consult updated country condition guidelines
Authority_Responsible: PRRA Officer, Federal Court (on judicial review)

Crime_Name: Discrimination complaint under the Canadian Human Rights Act
Dispute_Type: Human rights discrimination complaint regarding timeliness and discretionary extension
Legal_Issue: Whether the Commission erred in finding the complaint time-barred and failed to exercise discretion for an extension
Evidence_Assessment: Timing of key decisions and communications, including CIC's final decision in June 2004 and a letter from July 2003
Decision_Outcome: Commission's decision set aside; matter remitted for reconsideration
Burden_of_Proof: On the Applicant to justify delay and request for extension
Legal_Rule: Complaints must be filed within one year unless an extension is granted by the Commission
Grounds_for_Claim: Allegation that limitation period began in June 2004; challenge to Commission's procedural fairness and reasoning
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; case remitted for reconsideration
Key_Evidence_Considered: July 2003 letter as point of crystallization, December 2001 event cited by Respondent, June 2004 CIC decision
Legal_Framework: Canadian Human Rights Act, administrative law principles on discretion and procedural fairness
Defendant_Response: Argued that limitation period began in December 2001
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, setting aside of Commission's decision, remittal for reconsideration
Legal_Provision: Paragraph 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court

Application_Facts: Applicants claimed risk of persecution in Guatemala due to surname confusion with a former president
Procedural_Issue: PRRA officer's consideration of new evidence
Legal_Standard_Applied: PRRA officers must consider new evidence that arose after the rejection of the refugee claim or was not reasonably available at the time of the hearing
Decision_Rationale: The PRRA officer adequately assessed relevant evidence; no errors found in decision-making process

Application_Facts: Mr. Ryivuze held a high-ranking position in Burundi's government, knew about its crimes, and did not disassociate. His role contributed to government operations despite knowledge of atrocities.
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Used: Position in government, knowledge of crimes, failure to disassociate
Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious reasons to believe standard, lower than civil or criminal law
Decision_Rationale: Mr. Ryivuze was complicit by association due to his role, knowledge, and failure to disengage from a regime committing crimes against humanity

Legal_Issue: Concealment of identity as a Burundian civil servant in refugee application
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1)
Evidence_Type: Documentary and circumstantial evidence of government affiliation
Basis_of_Claim: Exclusion due to misrepresentation and complicity
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Voluntary association with government committing atrocities and concealment of identity
Legal_Standard: Lower standard than civil or criminal law
Application_Factor: High-ranking government role, knowledge, lack of disassociation
Document_Fraud: Concealment of identity as a civil servant

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious criminality under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Respondent pleaded guilty to cocaine trafficking, sentenced to three years with 30 months pre-sentence custody credited, leaving six months to serve.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Permanent Resident or foreign national subject to inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: IAD excluded pre-sentence custody from 'term of imprisonment' under s. 64(2) IRPA
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Interpretation of 'term of imprisonment' under federal immigration law
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Sentencing record, plea of guilt, credit for pre-sentence custody
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: IAD failed to consider pre-sentence custody as part of sentence
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD decision set aside, case referred for redetermination
Crimes.Outcome: Loss of appeal rights due to serious criminality confirmed
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn IAD decision on interpretation of term of imprisonment
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of s. 64(2) IRPA in light of s. 719(3) Criminal Code
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Pre-sentence custody forms part of the term of imprisonment under IRPA

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of cocaine for the purposes of trafficking
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether pre-sentence custody counts toward 'term of imprisonment' under IRPA s. 64(2)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Court assessed sentencing judge's credit for 30 months pre-sentence custody
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD decision overturned, case remitted for rehearing
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On immigration authorities to establish inadmissibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Pre-sentence custody is part of the sentence under s. 719(3) Criminal Code and included in 'term of imprisonment' under IRPA
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Erroneous interpretation of 'term of imprisonment' by IAD
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Respondent found to meet serious criminality threshold under IRPA
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Guilty plea, sentencing transcript, credit for pre-sentence custody
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Intersection of criminal sentencing and immigration law
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Pleaded guilty to possession for the purpose of trafficking
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (sentencing records), admissions
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certified question answered, IAD decision set aside
Crimes.Outcome: Appeal rights lost due to serious criminality; deportation order likely enforceable
Crimes.Authority: Immigration Appeal Division (IAD), Federal Court on judicial review

Crimes.Crime_Name: Potential terrorism-related activities under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Admission_or_Involvement: alleged ties with a terrorist organization

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility to Canada due to membership in a terrorist organization
Application_Facts: alleged ties with a terrorist group
Decision_Rationale: fairness and natural justice do not require appointment of special advocate due to sufficient disclosure

Crimes.Crime_Name: Subversion against democratic government, institutions or processes
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Reporting to the Chinese Embassy and attempting to subvert a Canadian student organization
Crimes.Target_Entity: Non-political student group (not democratic institutions or processes)
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Applicant reported to the Chinese Embassy and attempted to influence a student organization
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Activities not directed at democratic institutions
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of visa refusal based on alleged subversion
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Decision set aside; case remanded for reconsideration

Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Pattern of reporting to the Chinese Embassy and attempting to subvert a student organization
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Applicant suspected of engaging in subversive activities through reporting and organizational interference
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Lack of evidence linking actions to democratic institutions
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of permanent residence refusal
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Decision overturned; case remanded for reconsideration

Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Reporting on CSSA members to Chinese Embassy officials and attempting to subvert the organization
Crimes.Target_Entity: Student organization (CSSA), not democratic institutions or processes
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Applicant communicated information about CSSA members to foreign officials
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Actions did not meet legal threshold for espionage against democratic entities
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of alleged espionage leading to PR refusal
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Court allowed application; decision set aside and remanded

Crimes.Violation_Type: Visa overstay after refugee claim denial
Crimes.Application_Facts: Lowe entered Canada without a visa, was denied refugee status, and remained unlawfully
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: No procedural unfairness found in decision-making
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Immigration officer's assessment of marriage purpose
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Marriage deemed not genuine
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Remain in Canada via spousal sponsorship
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Exemption under s. 9(1) if marriage not for immigration purposes
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Marriage found to be primarily for immigration purposes; no procedural error

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Validity of marriage for immigration purposes
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether marriage was genuine or primarily for immigration benefit
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Marriage not considered genuine; cohabitation not established
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Official immigration inquiry findings
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Spousal sponsorship following failed refugee claim
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Marriage entered into primarily for immigration purposes
Crimes.Application_Error: No legal obligation to proceed with sponsorship
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Court cannot consider evidence outside original inquiry
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness and statutory compliance
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of illegal entry and failed refugee claim
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Motion dismissed; costs awarded against applicants

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the marriage was genuine or for immigration advantage
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Marriage assessed as primarily for immigration purposes
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration officer’s evaluation of relationship
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Request for spousal sponsorship after illegal entry
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Purpose of marriage being immigration-related
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review seeking prohibition, certiorari, mandamus
Crimes.Application_Error: No legal duty to reconsider denied application
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Procedural fairness and genuineness of marriage
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Court limited to record from original proceeding
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Absence of procedural unfairness or legal error
Crimes.Application_Factor: Marriage following denial of refugee status

Legal_Issue: Validity of Eli Lilly's Canadian Patent No. 2,209,735 for the use of atomoxetine to treat ADHD
Evidence_Assessment: MGH Study was too small and short-term to conclusively prove clinical utility; lack of disclosure of factual basis and reasoning for sound prediction
Decision_Outcome: '735 Patent is invalid due to inutility
Burden_of_Proof: On Novopharm to establish invalidity by a balance of probabilities
Credibility_Factor: Expert testimonies regarding prior art, MGH Study, and sufficiency of evidence
Legal_Rule: A patent must demonstrate utility, novelty, and non-obviousness; utility requires demonstrated effectiveness or sound prediction based on factual data and reasoning disclosed in the patent
Grounds_for_Claim: Obviousness, anticipation, lack of disclosure, inutility
Key_Evidence_Considered: MGH Study, expert testimony, prior art
Defendant_Response: Novopharm sought to invalidate the patent
Evidence_Type: Clinical study data, expert opinion, patent documentation
Outcome: Court declared the '735 Patent invalid and void

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Outcome: IAD’s decision overturned, case remanded for re-determination

Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Admission of police reports on acquitted charges

Evidence_Assessment: No widespread use of 'grill gear' in trade; design element adds distinctiveness
Credibility_Factor: New evidence presented on usage and distinctiveness
Legal_Rule: A trademark is not registrable if clearly descriptive or deceptively misdescriptive
Standard_of_Review: Whether the Registrar's decision was correct based on evidence
Grounds_for_Claim: Trademark rejection due to alleged descriptiveness
Key_Evidence_Considered: Usage of term 'grill gear', design component of mark
Outcome: Appeal allowed; Registrar's decision set aside
Authority: Registrar of Trademarks, Court on appeal

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed her visa and sought permanent residence on humanitarian grounds due to close ties with co-tenant and child in Canada
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of hardship to justify exemption
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds under subsection 25(1)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer found insufficient hardship to justify discretionary exemption; decision was within acceptable range of outcomes

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with Immigration and Refugee Protection Act requirements
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Denial of permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of Officer's assessment of humanitarian and compassionate factors
Evidence_Type: Parental ties to children in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Subsection 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds based on family ties
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Insufficient demonstration of hardship
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Humanitarian and compassionate considerations under IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Family relationships in Canada

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness and correct application of s. 19(1)(c.2) of the Immigration Act
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 19(1)(c.2)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Visa officer assessed credibility based on business ties and confidential information
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged false statements or omissions regarding criminal organization ties
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Ties to individuals and companies linked to triads
Crimes.Application_Error: None found by the court
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness and reasonableness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Prior notice and opportunity to respond provided

Crimes.Crime_Name: Reasonable grounds to believe involvement in criminal activity
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Interpretation of 'reasonable grounds' and 'member' under s. 19(1)(c.2)
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 19(1)(c.2)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Considered business links and confidential information
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On visa officer to establish reasonable grounds
Crimes.Legal_Rule: s. 19(1)(c.2) – inadmissibility for membership in criminal organization
Key_Evidence_Considered: Business relationships with known triad members
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Chiau denied ties and responded during interview

Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Whether applicant was given adequate opportunity to respond
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Confidential information not disclosed, but general concerns were communicated
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: No direct conviction, but alleged associations
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Reasonable grounds to believe membership in criminal organization
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Potential threat to public safety due to organized crime links
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Associations with triad-linked individuals and entities

Application_Facts: Applicant was absent from Canada for 171 days during the four-year period preceding the application, falling short of the required 1,095 days of physical residency
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet 1,095-day physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Inadequate reasons provided by Citizenship Judge; failure to explain calculations or consider all evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Judge did not adequately address or analyze submitted evidence including ICES and OHIP records
Remedy_Sought: New hearing before a different Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical residence requirement of 1,095 days in four years
Decision_Rationale: Decision found unreasonable due to lack of justification, transparency, and intelligibility in the Judge's reasoning
